title: 108_hr589
content: The Act is titled the "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings related to the commemoration. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. dedicated his life to securing liberty and justice for all citizens. He was a leading civil rights advocate, spearheading the movement in the 1950s and 1960s. King delivered his famous "I Have A Dream" speech at the March on Washington in 1963, emphasizing nonviolent resistance. Martin Luther King, Jr. advocated nonviolent resistance to end segregation and racial discrimination in America, earning the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize. Efforts are being made to preserve his personal papers for future study at the Library of Congress. All Americans should honor his legacy and strive for equality. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under specific sections of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain gold and silver for minting coins under this Act from various sources, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of coins minted under this Act will reflect the life and works of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. Coins will be issued under this Act. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary can start issuing coins from August 28, 2003, but minting authority will end on December 31, 2003. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Marketing efforts will be done in cooperation with the Legacy Fund. The Secretary, with the Legacy Fund, will develop a marketing program to promote and sell the coins issued under this Act in the US and internationally. SEC. 8. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $3 for the half dollar coin. Surcharges will be paid to the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Legacy Fund for its purposes. The Fund will be audited for the amounts received.
